captions.text: Thanks, Brian.

I am at the National Institute on Aging,
and as many of you know--

people are getting older, 
and there have been

advances in cancer research, 
cardiovascular disease research--

many people who would have died
in their 50s and 60s from those diseases

are living into the danger zone
for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.

It's projected that by 2050,
the number of people

with Alzheimer's disease
will triple from what it is today.

It's 5 million today, 
it'll be 15 million by 2050.

In my lab, we use a number
of different animal models

that are relevant to age-related
neurodegenerative disorders.

We have mice that accumulate 
amyloid in their brain as they get older,

and they have learning 
and memory problems.

We have mice that have damage
to dopamine producing neurons,

that control body movements--
that's Mylo-Parkinson's disease.

And we also have models of stroke,
which is again another major-rate problem
and cause of death.

Well, it has been known for a long time
that one way to extend

the life span of laboratory animals is
simply to reduce their energy intake.

And, in rats and mice one can increase
their life span by 30 or 40%.

We started looking at the effects
of energy restriction on the brain

in the context of age-related 
neurodegenerative disorders,

and found that we could slow down,
for example,

the abnormal accumulation of amyloid,
or the degeneration of dopamine neurons

in the Alzheimer's and Parkinson's myel
by reducing energy intake.

Now, there's a number of ways
you can reduce energy intake.
You can simply eat less at each meal,

or you can do what we call
intermittent fasting.
So, reduce the frequency of the meals.
And, what I am going to tell you today

is that fasting does good things
for the brain.

In the animals we have insight into
a lot of the neurochemical changes

that are occurring in the brain
that we think explain
why fasting is good for the brain.
But I am going to start out

and talk a little bit
about anecdotal evidence
that fasting is good for the brain,
and also evolutionary prospective

on why fasting might be good
for the brain.

OK. So everybody knows 
that in certain religions
people will fast periodically.
Down through history
many famous people with good brains
have fasted regularly.
Up on the top here is a quote from Plato,

he fasted for greater physical
and mental efficiency.
There are some quotes there,
including one from about 6,000 years ago,
an Egyptian pyramid inscription that says,

"Humans live on one-quarter
of what they eat;
on the other three-quarters live their doctors."

And in this country, as you know, 
being overweight is a big problem.

It's not only a risk factor for 
cardiovascular disease and diabetes,

certain cancers, 
but emerging evidence suggests

that it's also a risk factor
for age-related cognitive impairment,
and possibly Alzheimer's disease.

In the lower right,
there is a reference to a book

written over a hundred years ago 
by Upton Sinclair.

Many of you may know Upton Sinclair
is the author of "The Jungle",

a book on meatpacking industry,
but he also wrote and published the book

that you can find in the full text online,
it's called "The Fasting Cure".

In that book he interviewes 250 people 
who had some ailment

and went on fast
for various lengths of time,
and except in a handful of cases,
their health condition improved.

OK, before I focus on the brain, 
which will be the main part of my talk,
I just want to point out

that there is evidence 
not just from animals,

but from humans that fasting
is good for the body.
It will reduce inflammation,

it will reduce oxidative stress
in organ systems throughout the body,

and one thing that happens when you fast,
that does not happen

when you eat three meals a day,
is that your energy metabolism shifts
so that you start burning fats.

Every time you eat a meal
the energy goes into your liver
and it's stored in the form of glycogen--
and it's always tapped into first.

And it takes about 10 to 12 hours
before you deplete the glycogen stores
in your liver.

So, if you eat three meals a day
you never deplete the glycogen stores

in your liver, although if you exercise
you can.

And once you deplete 
the glycogen stores in your liver
then you start burning fats,

and you produce
what are called ketone bodies.

It turns out ketone bodies
are very good for your brain,
and I'll talk about that in a minute.
Now, we've done a lot of work on animals
in the 90s, between 15 and 20 years ago,

showing that intermittent fasting was
good for the brain,

then we started collaborating
with some investigators,

did some human studies
looking at effects on the body,
some that were shown on the last slide.

And then a producer at the BBC
named Michael Mosley

made a program on intermittent fasting
that was aired on the BBC,
it's been aired on PBS.
He wrote a book called "The Fast Diet".

And just in the last two years
there's been a flurry of books
on intermittent fasting for health,

and it's becoming what, I think--
some people may think it's a fad,
but hopefully people find some of these--

What do I mean by intermittent fasting,
and intermittent energy restriction?

There's a lot of variations, 
that there've been on used on this.

One sort-- a harsh one is 
every other day only eat 500 calories.

And in our human studies we've been doing
what's called the 5:2 diet,

where 2 days a week 
you only eat 500 calories,
the other 5 days you eat normally.
Eat healthy if you can.

In this book called "The 8-Hour Diet"
there's evidence that if you restrict

the time window that you eat each day
to 8 hours or less,
it'll have health benefits,

again, that's long enough
to shift the energy metabolism.
OK, why does fasting bolster brain power?

During development of your brain,
but also in the adult,
neurons are generated from stem cells.

They grow out their axons and dendrites,
they form connections with each other,
synapses, and communicate with each other.

During aging, many people-- 
their brain ages successfully,
they stay cognitively intact,

whereas, unfortunately,
others develop diseases.

We think the reason,
the main take-home message of this talk,
is fasting is a challenge to your brain,
and your brain responds to that challenge

of not having food by activating
adaptive stress response pathways

that help your brain cope with stress,
and resist disease.

Does this make sense 
in evolutionary terms?

Anything we talk about in biology,
we always have to ask the question,
"Why is it that way?

Why when we take animals and put them
on an intermittent fasting diet,

are their neurons protected, in mice,
of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease?

Why do they perform better 
when we test their learning and memory?"
It amazes.

Well, if you're hungry
and haven't found food,
you better figure out how to find food.

You don't want your brain to shut down
if you're hungry.

And, in fact, that's what we find
in the animals:
Nerve cell circuits are more active.

Some of the changes in the brain
that occur with intermittent fasting
also occur with vigorous exercise.

Now, most people, and Jeff this morning 
gave a nice talk

on showing the benefits
of exercise on him.

I think you probably found 
that it benefited your brain too? OK.
So, when we start looking at

what are the neurochemical changes
in the brain with intermittent fasting.
They are very similar to exercise.

Now on this slide, 
in the upper left picture,

the third boy on the right running,
that's my son, he is in the audience.

You can tell by the faces of the 3 kids--
they are in a cross-country race,
that's a challenge, right?

They are probably saying 
to themselves during the race--

I used to run races myself,
I still occasionally do--
"Why am I doing this?"

However, when they get done with the race,
they feel great, and they feel relaxed.

During the cross-country season
my wife and I--

It's very obvious our son's mood 
was better.
On the right, my daughter is in the white.

Her mood was better during
cross-country season.
Why is that?

Exercise and intermittent fasting
both increase the production of proteins

in the brain that are called
neurotrophic factors.

We discovered this many years ago, 
back when I was a postdoc
in Colorado in 1980s.

We found that these neurotrophic factors,
such as FGF, and one called BDNF,

brain-derived neurotrophic factor,
promote the growth of neurons,

promote the connection of neurons,
and the strengthening in synapses.
OK, so here is the idea:

Challenges to you brain, 
whether it's intermittent fasting,

vigorous exercise,
or what we are doing now,

hopefully if you haven't fallen asleep,
is cognitive challenges.

When this happens,
neurocircuits are activated,

levels of neurotrophic factors
such as BDNF increase.
That promotes the growth of the neurons,

the formation and strengthening
of synapses.

Also shown in the lower left,
it turns out both,

exercise and intermittent fasting,
and using your neurons, using your brain

can increase the production
of new nerve cells from stem cells,

at least in one region of your brain,
called the hippocampus,
which is shown here.

I mentioned ketones,
which come from burning fat,
and that happens during fasting.

The Romans discovered ketones
even though they had no idea,

they haven't taken any chemistry course,
or didn't know what it was.
People with epileptic seizures back then,

they thought they were possessed
by demons.

And they found if they take these people
and shut them in a room,

and don't feed them,
the demons will go away.
What's happening is:

ketones go up, and it's well known that
ketons suppress seizures,

and in fact, ketogenic diets 
are used to treat, even today,
patients with severe epilepsy.
We are doing my work in my lab

trying to understand
why ketones are good for neurons.

One reason is they provide
an alternative fuel for the neurons,

they boost the energy levels
in the neurons.
Recently we discovered that fasting,

by increasing BDNF levels in the brain,
as a neurotrophic factor,
can increase the number of mitochondria
in your nerve cells.

And I am not going to go 
into details of this slide,

but the mechanism is very similar
to the mechanism

where by exercising your muscles
increases the number of mitochondria
in your muscles.

The fasting is a mild energetic stress,
and the neurons respond adaptively

by increasing mitochondria,
which helps them produce more energy,

and in this paper cited down here,
"Nature Communications",
we recently showed that

by increasing the number
of mitochondria in neurons,

it can increase the ability of the neurons
to form and maintain synapses,

and thereby increase 
learning and memory ability.

In addition to the increasing
neurotrophic factors
and increasing neuronal bioenergetics,
we've found that intermittent fasting

will enhance the ability
of your nerve cells to repair DNA,
so right now-- and also probably exercise,
and also intellectual challenges.

And again, what's happening in this case
when you are using your neurons,
exercising your neurons,
it causes a mild oxidative stress,

and at the same time
that there is increased oxidative stress

the cells are enhancing their ability
to repair oxidative damage to DNA.

Why is it that the normal diet
is three meals a day plus snacks?

It isn't that it's the healthiest way,
eating pattern,

and that's my opinion, but I think
there's a lot of evidence to support that.

There are a lot of pressures
to have that eating pattern.
There's a lot of money involved.

The food industry,
are they going to make money
from skipping breakfast like I did today?
No, they are going to lose money.

If people fast the food industry 
loses money.
What about the pharmaceutical industries?

What if people do
some intermittent fasting,

and exercise periodically,
and they are very healthy?

Is the pharmaceutical industry
going to make any money on healthy people?
So, one challenge for a society,

and this is one of the purposes
of these TED Talks, hopefully,

is that communication is the way
to improve health.

People understanding what they can do
to improve their health

and then taking action,
like Jeff talked about
in his own talk this morning.

So, I would urge you to communicate,
and spread the word

that there are ways for people 
to be healthy,
and maybe we can do this even with--

Of course, I am working for NIH,
and one thing about NIH is

we are using your tax payer's money
to try to help your health.
We don't have a profit motive.

So, really one of the main reasons
I've got interested

in things like intermittent fasting,
exercise,

trying to understand
at the cellular molecular level,
what's happening in the brain.
This is research that isn't commonly done,

and it's not done at all
by pharmaceutical industries,
and it's not done so much.
So, I am going to end with this slide.

And thank you very much 
for your attention.

And try it out, you can just play around
with these kinds of diets,
and you may find...

What we found in our human studies 
though is it's kind of like exercise:

if you've never exercised before,
and you go and run 3 miles,
you are not going to feel good.
If you eat 3 meals a day,

and all of a sudden
you go all day not eating anything

that day you are going to feel irritable,
and ornery, and so on.

But it turns out if you can 
kind of force yourself to do that,

maybe one day a week for a month,
and then two days a week,

you get used to it,
and after a month or two

many people can adapt
to that kind of diet with no problem

and you'll find that on the days 
when you don't eat so much

you are more productive.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Why fasting bolsters brain power: Mark Mattson at TEDxJohnsHopkinsUniversity

comments.text:
My experience with fasting ( very rare ) corroborates the general tone of 
this talk; PROVIDED it is accompanied by appropriate self control. What 
grates on one's intelligence is the continuous reliance on intrusive 
experimentation using other creatures. This is surely counterintuitive; the 
insight acquired by restricting one's input to suit what is actually 
required ought to discourage these exceptionally stupid experiments; 
particularly since they suggest insignificant to useless "benefits to 
mankind" can be extrapolated from them; eg longer life.

If one's real intelligence can find ways to acquire a strong sense of the 
present, in tandem with a healthy disrespect for these misplaced 
intellectual exercises, we can claim real "progress" and not give a damn 
for the myth of "longevity", rather than that imposter should simply remain 
in the domain of collective scientific text, like a donkey carrying a load 
of books. When you boil it down pragmatically, however altruistic it 
sounds, making a heavily committed living this way, is the motive, 
collective and personal.

I aver that one can find, after sufficient study, a strong sense of the 
"present" "reality", following my ( text only ) video "THE QUIESCENT MIND - 
SIMPLE MYSTIC FREE APPROACH" ( see also latest comments ); and have 
experiences that the alcoholic drinkers, smokers and drug takers seek, but 
never fully obtain, due to the conflict between nature's metabolism and 
their alien destructive effect. There is no denying one's "best interest" 
is in the preservation of oneself, since it works out for the most logical 
balance of nature, that isn't so much discerned as a phenomenological 
concept in itself; it just gnaws at our primitive pysche with a true sense 
of its gross lack of concern for, and true understanding of, life itself, 
in all its "forms".﻿
comments.author: GotNoEvidence

This guy doesn't seem like he's in very good health for someone who 
advocates fasting... Is it just me who notices?﻿

comments.author: Farah anisah

comments.text:
i think my diet is the best for about six years i have been living on milk, 
every day I drink two gallons, or 7.5 liters, of cow milk, usually skim, 
and don't eat or drink anything else.  I can keep my weight down this way, 
i'm six one and about 160.  i think it's the best diet for brain power, and 
other measures of health, because milk doesn't clog and irritate your cells 
(including brain cells) as much as solid food.﻿
comments.author: Greg Dahlen

comments.text:
I remember one day of unintentional fasting. I was working in my garage and 
just worked through my hunger for several hours.

It was a completely, boring mundane job... except I felt absolutely 
fantastic afterwards. I remember having incredibly clear thinking, which 
I've not really had since then.

I should get back into fasting at least one day a week.

I think, like raw food, it's one of those elusive, yet obvious things that 
could be so helpful.﻿
comments.author: Robinson Road

comments.text:
When I go too long without eating (e.g., 2 hours past normal lunch time) I 
start to get a pounding headache. Can't tell if that is bolstering my brain 
power because the pain makes it impossible for me to concentrate. If I 
ignore it I get nauseated and shaky.﻿
comments.author: Elaine Keller

comments.text:
That's only because you're not used to it. It passes in a day or so. This 
can happen with any drop in calories, not just fasting.
comments.author: Jody Mack

comments.text:
Mr Mattson, you don't look too healthy to me.... Just saying. But great 
presentation! I know this from the Hygiene society going back 20 years... 
But my mom got rid of a fibroid tumor by fasting and eating raw vegetarian 
type meals and juicing, but now has Dementia as a result of eating that way 
and not eating meat and eggs. SO beware. I haven't watched the whole video 
so I am hoping you are not proposing to go full blown vegan here./﻿
comments.author: bertina Brown

comments.text:
happened to see this video on the same day i decided to fast.... Devine 
intervention? hmmm :D﻿
comments.author: Chew Maine F

comments.text:
This was such a good presentation.  My life has been so much better since I 
started fasting.  I consume 2,500 calories between 4 pm and 10 pm and then 
only drink water the other 18 hours of the day.  It took a while to get 
used to and I did get really grumpy in the beginning.  However, it was well 
worth it and has really enhanced my life.  I love going to bed full every 
night and skipping breakfast/lunch gives me more time for other activities. 
 I was really intrigued by all the brain benefits he listed.  I started 
fasting for body composition purposes and athletic performance.  I had no 
idea it was really that beneficial for your brain.  In my personal 
experience benefits of intermittent fasting are: increased strength gains, 
fat loss, mental clarity, and increased libido (a lot of increased libido).﻿
comments.author: Matthew Cassell

comments.text:
While fasting, people need to understand that it is crucial to also make 
sure you are getting the nutrients and vitamins necessary for normal body 
physiology.  Lots of diseases are linked w/ chronic vitamin deficiency.  

The best way to improve brain power is said in his presentation and as well 
as other people commenting; EXERCISE + PROPER NUTRITION = BOLSTERING BRAIN 
POWER.﻿
comments.author: Ricky Bains

comments.text:
Fasting gets the survival instinct flowing. Seems to help you think and 
react even, like the pressure is on to your body, not having had food in 
days. It's an interesting feeling/reaction, I've fasted many times myself. 
It may bolster brain power a little but I can tell you not eating 
definitely did not bolster my body... lol.﻿
comments.author: Deathbrewer

comments.text:
Dr.Mattson is reporting on the growing scientific evidence on this 
on-going,complex research. The data being gathered in his on-going research 
is very difficult. The extensive findings that he summarizes here are 
actually very simple and confirmation of this evidence continues each year. 
Before the comments below go ALL CAPS about religious or historical 
ideologies, please remember that you can build on his facts or ignore the 
facts. Ignoring the facts does not change the facts. The cells of the body 
are healthier when the body receives less calories and gets more exercise. 
We all want to grow old but not "Be Old"..I look forward to more of his 
evidence..﻿

attention trouble itself over the "non objective", since all must be 
subjective; for obvious reasons.

I eat a moderately high fat vegetarian diet (about 40% fat). I've started 
dabbling in intermittent fasting. I love it. But I haven't gone multiple 
days or anything. The furthest I've gone is miss breakfast and lunch and 
then workout with weights and running. I think I'm pretty "fat adapted" 
because that was easy. Frighteningly easy. I still wasn't hungry. I just 
ate something because I thought it would be a good idea after working out. 
But I felt I could have gone for days. It's pretty strange.

in that all of your senses become heightened and you reach a state of 
clarity. You are not hungry after 6 days (is true) and by day 5 or 6, you 
no longer want to "dirty yourself" by eating again (altho you will by 
breaking the fast properly). I followed a book by Paavo Airola.
comments.author: Jeffrey Cella

comments.text:
I wonder how exercise effects lifespan in regards to the benefits obtained 
by calorie restriction.  Is it just calories which get stored as fat that 
contribute to a shorter lifespan, or is it the totality of calories 
consumed (regardless of if you have the exercise induced metabolism to 
utilize those calories)?  It sounds like, for brain function, the exercise 
induced increase in metabolism produces the same effects as calorie 
restriction (or limits the necessary calorie restriction to achieve the 
same effect).  I've lifted weights for 26 years now, and I have to eat 4 to 
5 thousand calories a day to maintain my muscle mass.  I often wonder if, 
by having such a high metabolism, and consuming so many overall calories 
(even though I have a low bodyfat % and consume good foods), if my life 
will be shorter just on the basis of all that extra cellular repair and 
calorie processing.  I suspect it's going to be bad for me, but I sure 
would like to hear from anybody familiar with any research or studies that 
might give me some insight. ﻿

comments.text: Fascinating talk ﻿
comments.author: Mags Durand

comments.text:
I usually eat only once a day, and sometimes not every day. People tend to 
tell me that this is extremely unhealthy compared to three meals a day, and 
that I should eat more regularly. But is that true?

Mark Mattson suggests that this might not be true. Fasting (as well as 
exercise and intellectual stimulation) can be very good for your brain and 
health more generally. From my experience, I feel pretty great without 
food, and I almost never feel an urge to eat (although I do get thirsty a 
lot, so maybe I just confuse those two signals). I also finish my best work 
during fasts, although the causality here is unclear since I usually just 
forget that I need to eat when I am absorbed in my work.

/cc +David Basanta (for the running references) and +Jacob Scott (because 
he might know more about the actual health aspects). /via +Russ Abbott ﻿
comments.author: Artem Kaznatcheev

comments.text:
+teetoo labalaba The NBA player, at least one of them, that I was thinking 
of was Hakeem Olajuwon.  In 1995, Ramadan started February 1, yet Hakeem 
Olajuwon was named NBA Player of the Month for February of that year.  He 
played hard even on days where he had not eaten for twelve hours.  I'm not 
saying everyone can do this, but we're capable of a lot more than we 
sometimes credit ourselves.
comments.author: jdstep97

comments.text:
+teetoo labalaba I think we can probably do whatever we set our minds 
to.  I have never done manual labor as a living, but my ex husband has, and 
there were days he ate maybe one meal late at night.  During the day, 
especially when hot, he mostly drank a lot of water.  He said that eating 
an actual meal made him less productive.  But he probably was snacking.  If 
your body is getting the nutrition it needs, a lot of time you're simply 
not hungry.  But ever body is different.  We all have to do what is best 
for ourselves. 

I remember a Muslim NBA player was fasting during the month of Ramadan, and 
he said that he performed just as well as he did when not fasting.  And he 
only ate a few dates before sunrise and drank, I think, maybe two gallons 
of water.  I can't remember his name.  If it comes to me, I'll come back 
and write it.
comments.author: jdstep97

comments.text:
What do you work as? Heavy manual workers cannot possibly do what u do. 
Emergency room doctors cannot either.

I am a woman, but one of the people I admire most in the vegan community 
is Jim Morris.  He is over 75 and is a weight lifter.  In a YouTube video (*Jim 
Morris - LT Interview*, at about 6:45), he talked about eating just one 
meal a day.  He gives me inspiration.  You can look as good as you can at 
whatever age.

Artem i think you may be lucky.  
    If your body and mind feel good eating less, then it's probably very 
good for you most of the time
comments.author: MsCordially

comments.text:
i started doing 16 hour intermittent fasts a few days ago, and the benefits 
have been tremendous. in fact, it really surprises me just how much 
something so tiny could have such a big impact on my overall emotional and 
spiritual, as well as physical, health. one must be careful about overdoing 
it, however. when i do eat, i need to make sure that i am not only getting 
enough calories, but that what i am eating is nutritionally dense. this is 
especially true since i exercise regularly, which can make one prone to 
overtraining.
comments.author: Nikolaus Wischkowsky

comments.text:
My current policy when it comes to food is to try to eat a bit less each 
time. I am assuming that I could do this at a linear pace so I can reduce 
what I eat by the same amount each day. I am hoping that in a short while I 
might be able to subsist by not eating anything at all. Ideally, I will be 
able to just produce food myself (going negative) and feed the world?
comments.author: David Basanta

comments.text:
For the past 2 weeks or so ive been eating, fasting, and then eating. I 
fast every other day. And when I do it, its usually in a 4 hour window. I 
eat a bunch of Guacamole, beans, Kale, and sometimes fish. The funny thing 
is that I feel a little bit hungry on fasting days, but I just ward it off 
with water & I feel just fine. The crazy thing is that on the days that I 
am supposed to eat, I really dont feel hungry at all. I actually feel even 
better on those days. Im going to try and keep this up for as long as I 
can. I really like it, but I too am not sure if im overdoing it. This talk 
makes me feel alot better about it though.
comments.author: caveman_35seven

comments.text:
I am very similar to you in this Artem. I am 60 years old and have done 
this throughout life since my teens. I did 6 days of clear liquids about a 
month ago and felt outstanding. I could have gone many days longer and will 
after the holidays. The first three days are the most challenging but after 
that it's so freeing not to think or be concerned about food. Can't wait to 
do a longer fast soon.
comments.author: Darris B. Nelson

comments.text:

physically demanding job.

comments.text:
haha.  Yeah, this talk isn't that great. But some of them on the subject of 
fasting are really good...like they will show you the benefits of fasting 
which help motivate people to do it and prepare for it(like take a week off 
from work...stuff like that because they know what to expect.) I have found 
that during a fast, when you feel bad, you feel REALLY bad(tired, cant 
think straight, etc...), and when you feel good, you feel GREAT. It's like 
being physically bipolar. But eventually the bad changes to just being good 
when you do it long enough and the body has gotten rid of the bad stuff in 
the body and heals.

comments.text:
I ate one meal a day for three days leading up to the fast I am on now.  
I haven't eaten in 36 hours and I'm so hungry!  I can't go 10 minutes 
without thinking about food and I'm finding this really challenging to do.  
Don't know if I want to aim for 48 hours or 60 but right now I'm trying to 
make it through today without getting too cranky.﻿

comments.author: Raymond Duplesse

comments.text:
this nation is all about money and profits... so food industry would loose 
money by people eating less meals, plus pharmaceutical industry would loose 
money if people were healthy... this man speaks the truth about 
intermittent fasting... 
i have been on an intermittent fasting diet for the past three weeks, 
restricting food intake to two meals a day within a 4-6 hour window. my 
calorie intake remains about 2200 per day but im loosing weight 
consistently without losing muscle mass. i also work out 3-4 times a week. 
we've been fed a lie for so long, eat three meals a day to be healthy, or 
eat six meals a day to boost metabolism. so it should come as a shock when 
the speaker goes against what we've been hearing all our lives.
my suggestion is much like the speakers, do some research and try it to see 
if it works for you. ﻿
